Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) images of the meso‑CeCoOx-300 (a–c), meso‑CeCoOx-400 (d–f), meso‑CeCoOx-500 (g–i), and meso‑CeCoOx-600 (j–l), and EDS mapping of meso‑CeCoOx-300 (m). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption desorption isotherms (a) and BJH pore size distributions (b) of SBA-15 and meso‑CeCoOx catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Low angle XRD patterns of SBA-15 and meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalysts (a), High angle XRD patterns meso‑CeCoOx catalysts (b), Raman spectrum of meso‑CeCoOx catalysts (c). State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation and National Engineering Research Center for Fine Petrochemical Intermediates Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou 730000 China In this paper, a novel vacuum in-situ confined encapsulation strategy was proposed, in which Co-MOFs were embedded and anchored into ordered mesoporous CeO2 structure to obtain a precursor of Co-MOF@CeO2 composites. Accordingly, the Co-MOF@CeO2 precursor was transformed into ordered mesoporous CeCoOx oxides for catalytic combustion of toluene by precisely controlling their calcination temperature without destroying the ordered mesoporous structure. It is confirmed that order meso‑CeCoOx-300 calcined at 300 °C had superior activity and good thermal stability for toluene catalytic oxidation, which were chiefly due to the content of Co3+, the effective anchoring of Co-MOFs in ordered mesoporous CeO2, more lattice oxygen, and weak acid sites. More importantly, we discovered that the active Co species would migrate and aggregate with the increase of calcination temperature, and affected greatly the interaction between Ce and Co. Besides, the increase of calcination temperature also resulted in an obvious decrease of the specific surface area and Co3+ species (TOFs) of the catalysts, which affected the catalytic combustion activity of toluene. Graphical abstract A novel vacuum in-situ confinement encapsulation strategy was proposed, in which Co-MOFs was embedded and anchored into ordered mesoporous CeO2 structure to obtain ordered mesoporous CeCoOx bimetallic oxide for catalytic combustion of toluene. It is discovered that the order meso‑CeCoOx-300 calcined at 300 °C had superior activity and good thermal stability for toluene catalytic oxidation due to the effective anchoring of Co-MOFs in ordered mesoporous CeO2 pores. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ordered mesoporous CeCoOx VOCs In-situ confined encapsulation strategy Catalytic combustion 1 Introduction With rapid industrialization and urbanization around the world, compound air pollution characterized by O3 and PM2.5 has become increasingly prominent. Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are important precursors of secondary pollution such as ozone (O3) and fine particulate matter (PM2.5), which cause serious harm to the natural environment and human health [1–3]. Hence, it is extremely urgent to develop an effective method to eliminate VOCs. Catalytic oxidation technology is considered an effective method to eliminate VOCs due to its characteristics of low operating temperature, high destruction efficiency, and less secondary pollution [4,5]. However, the core of catalytic oxidation technology is to develop high-performance catalysts. In recent years, non-precious metal catalysts have attracted widespread attention in various fields due to their low application cost and good performance. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are skeleton materials composed of metal ions and organic ligands and have a rich spatial topological structure [6,7]. As a new material, it has received widespread attention in the field of catalysis due to its advantages such as huge specific surface area, ultra-high porosity, adjustable pore size, and abundant organic ligands [8–10]. In particular, the Co-based catalyst derived from Co-MOFs exhibits excellent VOCs oxidation performance due to their rich reactive oxygen species, rich high valence Co ions, and sufficient acid sites. For example, Ren et al. [11] synthesized three-dimensional layered Co3O4 nano-catalysts with different morphology and exposed crystal surface through a hydrothermal method. The results showed that 3D hierarchical cube stacked Co3O4 microspheres (C sample) had the best catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. It is considered that the high specific surface area, abundant oxygen species on the surface, and more Co3+ species are the reasons for its excellent catalytic performance. Zhao et al. [12] successfully synthesized a series of hollow Co3O4 polyhedrons of different sizes through the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 for the catalytic oxidation of toluene. The effects of different dimensions of hollow Co3O4 polyhedron catalytic combustion of toluene were systematically studied. Through a series of characterization, it was found that the catalytic performance of hollow Co3O4 polyhedron was significantly improved with the increase of Co3+ species. Furthermore, the large number of oxygen species adsorbed on the surface can accelerate the catalytic combustion of toluene. However, in our previous research work [13–15], it was found that most of the Co-based catalysts derived from Co-MOFs had poor thermal stability. Therefore, the development of catalysts with high thermal stability is very important for our research. It is noteworthy that ordered mesoporous materials have been used as a very promising substrate material in the field of catalysis due to their special pore structure [16–18]. Usually, metal nanoparticles can be anchored to the interior of ordered mesoporous material channels, thus effectively improving the thermal stability of metal nanoparticles. For example, Li et al. [19] prepared ordered mesoporous Mg-SBA-15 catalysts with high specific surface area by a one-pot hydrothermal process. The results show that, compared with Mg/SBA-15-IM synthesized by the impregnation method, Mg-SBA-15 synthesized by the one-pot hydrothermal method has better dispersion for metals, and further improves the thermal stability of metal nanoparticles. Chen et al. [20] assembled a novel composite HKUST-1@SBA-15 using an in-situ hydrothermal method. The SBA-15 matrix not only acts as a structural guiding agent during the directional growth of HKUST-1 nanocrystals but also provides ordered morphology and hierarchical structure. According to characterization analysis, compared with HKUST-1, the composite HKUST-1@SBA-15 showed better thermal stability due to the addition of SBA-15. Xiang et al. [21] prepared mesoporous Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (Si-MCeZr) with different Si/(Ce+Zr) molar ratios by using an optimized evaporation-induced self-assembly method. The results showed that the addition of silica significantly improved the thermal stability of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 at a high temperature (700 °C). Therefore, we expect to improve the thermal stability of Co-based catalysts derived from Co-MOFs by anchoring Co-MOFs into the pore structures of ordered mesoporous materials. In addition, considering the VOCs oxidation reaction requires an efficient charge transfer rate. Therefore, ordered mesoporous CeO2 was selected as the substrate material for encapsulating Co-MOFs. The highly dispersed Co species and the introduction of mesoporous catalysts expose more active sites, which is conducive to the proximity of reactive molecules to active sites, thus improving the mass transfer efficiency of reactants and product molecules [22]. Herein, in this work two-dimensional ordered mesoporous CeO2 metal oxide was prepared by "nano-casting technique" using two-dimensional ordered mesoporous silicon oxide (SBA-15) as a hard template. On this basis, a new vacuum in-situ confinement encapsulation strategy was proposed, in which Co-MOFs were embedded and anchored into ordered mesoporous CeO2 structure to prepare a precursor of Co-MOFs@CeO2 composites with ordered mesoporous channel structure. Finally, the Co-MOFs@CeO2 precursor was transformed into CeCoOx bimetallic oxide by precisely controlling the calcination temperature without destroying the ordered mesoporous structure. We found that the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst has excellent catalytic performance (T90=220 °C) and good stability for toluene catalytic oxidation. Through a series of chemical characterization, it is confirmed that the presence of more Co3+ species, more lattice oxygen species, smaller Co nanoparticles, and weak acid sites are some key factors to improve the activity and stability of meso‑CeCoOx catalyst. More importantly, we discovered that the active Co species would migrate and aggregate with the increase of calcination temperature, and affected greatly the interaction between Ce and Co. Besides, the increase of calcination temperature also resulted in an obvious decrease of the specific surface area and Co3+ species (TOFs) of the catalysts, which affected the catalytic oxidation activity of toluene. 2 Experimental stage 2.1 Synthesis of SBA-15 template According to the former research [23,24], SBA-15 with two-dimensional hexagonal through-hole structure was synthesized. In the process of synthesis, 4.0 g P123 was dissolved in 150 ml, 1.6 mol/L hydrochloric acid solution, and stirred at 40 °C, followed by 8.4 g of TEOS. After stirring for a day, the mixture was reacted at 100 °C for 24 h. Then, it was washed by centrifugal water and dried under vacuum at 80 °C, and then the white powder was obtained and calcined at 550 °C (2 °C/min) for 5 h. 2.2 Synthesis of mesoporous CeO2 (meso‑CeO2) and pure Co3O4 First, 2.5 g of Ce(NO3)3•6H2O dissolved in 15 ml of ethanol solution, stirred for a period of time, and 1 g of SBA-15 powder prepared was added after it was completely dissolved. This solution was stirred until a dry powder was formed, and then calcined at 300 °C for 5 h to pyrolyze the nitrate, and the resulting powder from the pyrolysis was denoted as A. Again, 1.95 g Ce(NO3)3•6H2O dissolved in 15 ml of ethanol solution, stirred for a period of time, and A was added to the solution after it was completely dissolved. Then stir until a dry powder is formed. The powder was calcined at 500 °C for 5 h to form a composite material of mesoporous silicon and metal oxide. The obtained composite material was added to a 2 mol/L NaOH solution to remove the mesoporous silicon. Finally, the sample was washed and dried to obtain mesoporous CeO2. The pure Co3O4 were prepared by thermal treatment of Co(NO3)2•6H2O. The samples were heated at 400 °C for 1 h with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 in air. 2.3 Construction of ordered mesoporous CeCoOx oxide catalyst Under the condition of 25 °C water bath, 0.5 g of ordered mesoporous CeO2 is treated under vacuum for 10 min to remove the impurity gas in the pore structure. 30 mg CTAB (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide) dissolved in 20 ml of deionized water and mixed evenly, then 0.58 g Co(NO3)2•6H2O was added to form A solution. 9.08 g 2-methylimidazole was added to 140 ml deionized water to form B solution. Then, 28 ml of solution B was added dropwise to ordered mesoporous CeO2 adsorption and degassing under vacuum and 25 °C for 10 min, and 4 ml of A solution was added dropwise to the precursor under vacuum environment for stirring. The self-assembly reaction was carried out for 30 min under vacuum conditions, and the resulting solution was allowed to stand at 25 °C in a vacuum box for 12 h. After that, the meso‑ZIF-67@CeO2 precursor was obtained via centrifugal washing, drying overnight at 60 °C. Raise the temperature of 1 °C min−1 to 300 °C, 400 °C, 500 °C, 600 °C and keep it for 5 h to convert the meso‑ZIF-67@CeO2 precursor into order mesoporous CeCoOx bimetal oxide. The samples obtained are expressed as meso‑CeCoOx-300, meso‑CeCoOx-400, meso‑CeCoOx-500, meso‑CeCoOx-600, respectively. To compare with meso‑CeCoOx-300 prepared by Co-MOF, we added 0.58 g of Co(NO3)2•6H2O to 20 ml of deionized water, stirred to complete dissolution, then added 0.5 g of ordered mesoporous CeO2, stirred at 25 °C, and then directly dried, and calcined at 300 °C to obtain catalyst Co3O4/CeO2–300. 2.4 Characterization of the CoCeOx catalyst The morphology of the catalyst samples was analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (JEOL-JEM-2010). The specific surface area and pore diameter of the catalyst was measured on the Micromeritics ASAP 2010 analyzer by the method of low-temperature nitrogen adsorption and desorption. The composition of products was recorded by XRD patterns. The FTIR analysis of the sample adopts Fourier infrared spectrometer (Nexus 870, Nicolet), and ATR technology was used for FTIR analysis. The Raman spectroscopy test was performed on the LabramHR Evolution Raman spectrometer with a 532 nm laser source and a scanning range of 100 to 1200 cm−1. Escalab 250Xi photoelectron spectroscopy was used to detect the element composition and valence of the sample surface. The multifunctional dynamic adsorption instrument DAS-7000 was used to analyze the acidity and redox capacity of the catalyst surface. For H2-TPR, a 100 mg sample was heated from room temperature to 900 °C in reduced gas with volume fractions of 5 Vol% H2 and 95 Vol% N2, and the detector signal was continuously recorded. For the O2-TPD test, the catalyst (100 mg) was pretreated with nitrogen (99.9%) for 1 h at 300 °C. When the temperature drops to 50 °C, the O2 adsorption was carried out for 60 min. After the adsorption is over, purged with pure He for 0.5 h, and the desorbed O2 signal is detected at 50–900 °C. The temperature-programmed desorption operation of NH3-TPD is similar to that of O2-TPD, except that O2 is changed to NH3. 2.5 Evaluation of catalytic activity In the steady-state flow mode, a fixed-bed flow reactor was used to determine the catalytic activity of toluene. A mixture of 0.6 g of catalyst (40–60 mesh) and 0.5 g of quartz sand was added to the reactor with an inner diameter of 1 cm and a length of 30 cm. The reaction gas containing toluene (3000 ppm) is produced through the toluene saturator bubbler air and then through the reactor with a weight per hour spatial velocity (WHSV) of 20,000 mL g−1 h−1. The reaction temperature was first raised to 100 °C and stabilized for 2 h. The VOC conversion between the inlet and outlet gas was analyzed by GC-6820 gas chromatography and flame ionization detector. The following formula was used to evaluate the apparent activation energy (Ea, kJ mol−1) values of several catalysts: (2) r = − k c = [ − A exp ( − E a R T ) ] C (3) r = F W [ − I n ( 1 − x ) ] Among them, r, k, A, c, and Ea are the reaction rate (mol s−1), the reaction rate constant (s−1), exponential factor, VOC concentration, and activation energy of the catalyst, respectively. In addition, F is the toluene injection rate, W is the catalyst mass (0.6 g), and x is the toluene conversion rate. Eq. TOFs value can be used to measure the rate of the catalytic reaction of the catalyst, indicating the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. In this work, assuming Co as the active center, the TOFs values for the different catalysts used to eliminate toluene were calculated by the formula (5): (5) T O F = ( P v / R T ) η m ϖ C o M C o Where P = 0.101 Mpa, R = 8.314 J mol−1 K−1, v is toluene flow rate, η is toluene conversion at the corresponding temperature (473 K), m is the mass of catalyst used in the reaction (0.6 g), ωCo is the mass fraction of Co, MCo is the relative molecular weight of Co. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Design concept Generally, the superior redox properties of a Co-based catalyst are advantageous for enhancing its catalytic performance. Therefore, the reducible mesopore CeO2 was selected as support to anchor Co nanoparticles. In addition, we also found in our former work [30] that the Co3O4/SiO2 catalyst had poor activity for toluene oxidation due to the bad redox properties. In this work, to improve the low-temperature catalytic activity and thermal stability of Co-based catalysts, meso‑CeCoOx catalyst was synthesized through in-situ confinement encapsulation of Co-MOFs in order mesoporous CeO2. Firstly, SBA-15 was synthesized under acidic conditions using triblock copolymer P123 as template and TEOS as the silicon source. Then, using SBA-15 as a template, mesoporous CeO2 with high thermal stability was synthesized by the "nano-casting method". Subsequently, under vacuum conditions, the Co-MOFs were embedded and anchored into the ordered mesoporous CeO2 structure through "in-situ packaging technology", and make full use of its confinement effect to control the growth of Co-MOFs in a specific direction, and then prepare a Co-MOFs@CeO2 composite precursor with a regular and ordered mesoporous structure. By precisely controlling the calcination temperature, the order Co-MOF@CeO2 composite precursor was transformed into order mesoporous CeCoOx oxides. The preparation process of the order meso‑CeCoOx catalyst is shown in Scheme 1. 3.2 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic performance of order meso‑CeCoOx samples, pure Co3O4, and meso‑CeO2 to toluene oxidation was studied, as shown in Fig. 1 a. The graph depicts toluene conversion at temperatures ranging from 100 to 400 °C. Three parameters, T10, T50, and T90, corresponding to the temperatures of 10%, 50%, and 90% conversion, were used to compare the activity of the catalysts. Table 1 summarizes the T10, T50, and T90 of the meso‑CeCoOx, pure Co3O4 and meso‑CeO2 catalysts. Table 1 shows that the T10 of meso‑CeCoOx-300, meso‑CeCoOx-400, meso‑CeCoOx-500, meso‑CeCoOx-600, pure Co3O4 and meso‑CeO2 catalysts are 194 °C, 213 °C, 222 °C 237 °C, 250 °C and 256 °C, respectively, the T50 are 209 °C, 229 °C, 248 °C, 268 °C, 272 °C, 400 °C, respectively. The T90 of meso‑CeCoOx-300, meso‑CeCoOx-400, meso‑CeCoOx-500, meso‑CeCoOx-600, and pure Co3O4 catalysts are 220 °C, 240 °C, 260 °C, 280 °C and 320 °C, respectively. By comparison, the catalytic oxidation performance of meso‑CeCoOx-300 to toluene is better than other catalysts. In addition, we tested the performance of meso‑CeCoOx-300 at WHSV=40,000 mL g−1 h−1 and compared it to that at WHSV=20,000 mL g−1 h−1, as shown in Fig. S1a. Obviously, the catalytic performance of meso‑CeCoOx-300 for toluene decreased significantly at WHSV=40,000 mL g−1 h−1 (T90=450 °C). At the same time, in order to highlight the advantages of Co-MOF, Co3O4/CeO2–300 was prepared by impregnating Co(NO3)2•6H2O on meso‑CeO2 and compared with meso‑CeCoOx-300 prepared by Co-MOF method. Through their performance tests, it was found that the catalytic performance of meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst (T90=220 °C) prepared by Co-MOF for toluene was significantly better than that of Co3O4/CeO2–300 catalyst (T90=365 °C) obtained by impregnation (Fig. S1b). For comparison with previously reported Co-based catalysts, the catalytic activity of our typical sample for the catalytic oxidation of toluene is summarized in Table 2 . The results showed that meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst had a better catalytic activity to toluene than the samples reported previously. In addition, the activity can also be evaluated by comparing the apparent activation energy (Ea) value, where the low activation energy of the sample indicates good activity [25]. Based on Fig. 1b, the toluene oxidation reaction was controlled within the dynamic region (toluene conversion < 20%), and the Ea value was evaluated by the slope of Arrhenius curve. According to the slope of the Arrhenius diagram, Table 1 calculates and summarizes the Ea values. The Ea values of the six catalysts follow the following order: meso‑CeCoOx-300 (44.54 kJ/mol) < meso‑CeCoOx-400 (47.59 kJ/mol) < meso‑CeCoOx-500 (52.76 kJ/mol) < meso‑CeCoOx-600 (53.22 kJ/mol) < Co3O4 (54.62 kJ/mol) < (72.41 kJ/mol) . The Ea value is inversely proportional to the activity, confirming the superior activity of meso‑CeCoOx-300. At the same time, in order to compare the catalytic performance of meso‑CeCoOx in detail, we also calculated the catalyst surface reaction rate RS (reaction rate based on the specific surface area of the catalyst). It can be seen that the RS values of the catalyst at different temperature follow the order: meso‑CeCoOx-300 > meso‑CeCoOx-400 > meso‑CeCoOx-500 > meso‑CeCoOx-600 (Fig. S1c). To further verify that the surface Co species are the main active sites for the catalytic oxidation of toluene, we also calculated the conversion frequencies (TOFs) of meso‑CeCoOx and Co3O4 at 200 °C according to formula (5). The results are shown in Fig. 1c and Table 1. As shown in Table 1, the TOFs values of the five catalysts follow meso‑CeCoOx-300 (4.421 × 10−6 s−1) > meso‑CeCoOx-400 (3.625 × 10−6 s−1) > meso‑CeCoOx-500 (3.095 × 10−6 s−1) > meso‑CeCoOx-600 ((3.006 × 10−6 s−1) > Co3O4 (1.857 × 10−6 s−1). It is discovered that the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst showed a high TOFs value, indicating the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst owns the best activity for toluene oxidation reaction. 3.3 Characterization of the catalyst 3.3.1 Morphology of the catalysts To observe the microstructure of the catalyst more intuitively, the catalysts meso‑CeCoOx was characterized by TEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2, meso‑CeCoOx-300 (Fig. 2 (a–c)), meso‑CeCoOx-400 (Fig. 2 (d–f)), meso‑CeCoOx-500 (Fig. 2 (g–i)), and meso‑CeCoOx-600 (Fig. 2 (j–l)) show an ordered mesoporous structure. These results showed that all four samples had good reverse replication of the SBA-15 template (TEM of SBA-15 is shown in Fig. S2), and the ordered mesoporous structures were well preserved after the nano casting replication. In addition, the catalyst has a smooth outer surface, on which no obvious nanoparticles were observed, indicating that almost all Co3O4 nanoparticles successfully entered the mesoporous CeO2 channel. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern is shown in the illustrations (Fig. 2c, f, i, and l). It is obvious from Fig. 2 that there are multiple bright electron diffraction rings, indicating that the crystallinity of the four samples is relatively good. The mapping diagram of the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst is shown in Fig. 2m, indicating that the catalyst is mainly composed of Ce, Co, and O elements, and all elements are uniformly distributed in the pores of ordered mesoporous CeO2. At the same time, it shows that the Co-MOFs and meso‑CeO2 are successfully combined, and the Co element is evenly distributed in the mesopores of CeO2. 3.3.2 Surface area and porosity analysis Fig. 3 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of SBA-15 and four meso‑CeCoOx catalysts. According to the IUPAC classification, all catalysts show a typical type IV isotherm with H1 hysteresis loop, which is closely related to the formation of many mesoporous structures, indicating that the catalyst has a typical mesoporous structure [26,27]. These results indicate that all four samples have well copied the SBA-15 template and well preserved the ordered mesoporous structures after nano casting, which is consistent with the TEM observation. In addition, Table 3 shows more quantitative data on the catalyst characteristics of the four meso‑CeCoOx and SBA-15. The specific surface area and pore volume of the original SBA-15 were 717.32 m2 g−1 and 1.05 cm3 g−1 respectively, and the average pore diameter was 6.3 nm. It can be seen that as the calcination temperature increases, the specific surface area of the meso‑CeCoOx catalyst decreases from 126.79 m2 g−1 to 117.69 m2 g−1. Compared with SBA-15, the above results show that metal nanoparticles are successfully incorporated into mesoporous channels. Interestingly, meso‑CeCoOx-500 also has a large specific surface area at the calcination temperature of 500 °C, which may be related to the dispersion of metal particles. In addition, compared with the other three catalysts, the meso‑CeCoOx-600 catalyst has a larger average pore size, but its activity is lower, which is because that the increase of calcination temperature may lead to the growth and aggregation of nanoparticles, which may lead to partial blockage of mesoporous channels, thus reducing the catalytic oxidation performance of toluene [23]. 3.3.3 Phase structure analysis In order to further study the crystalline phase of the composite, SBA-15 and the meso‑CeCoOx-300 were tested by low angle XRD (Fig. 4 a). The low angle XRD spectrum shows that there are three obvious diffraction peaks on the support SBA-15, corresponding to the (100), (110) and (200) planes of SBA-15, respectively. The existence of these diffraction peaks indicates that the support SBA-15 has a highly ordered two-dimensional hexagonal through-hole structure. However, after removing the SBA-15 template, the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst did not show an obvious diffraction peak, which indicates that it may have a partially ordered mesoporous structure, which is consistent with the results observed by TEM. To determine the internal molecular structure of each catalyst, the high angle XRD diffraction curves of meso‑CeCoOx catalysts are shown in Fig. 4b. All the catalysts showed good crystallinity, which is consistent with the TEM characterization results. The diffraction peaks at 28.5, 33.0, 47.4, 56.3, 59.0, 69.4, 76.6, and 79.1° are assigned to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), and (420) planes of the cubic ceria phase (PDF#34–0394), it shows that the meso‑CeCoOx-300, meso‑CeCoOx-400, meso‑CeCoOx-500 and meso‑CeCoOx-600 catalysts have typical firopyrite structures [28,29]. The diffraction peaks at 36.8 and 65.2° correspond to the (311) and (440) planes of the spinel Co3O4 phase (PDF#42–1467) [30]. Both spinel Co3O4 phase and cubic cerium oxide phase appeared in the four catalysts, indicating that Co3O4 and mesoporous CeO2 combined successfully. Moreover, we found that the diffraction peaks of the spinel Co3O4 phase in all samples are weak, which may be due to the lower content of Co species and its good dispersibility. The average crystal size of CeO2 is calculated by Scherrer's formula using CeO2 (111) crystal plane data, and the results are shown in Table 3.The crystal size of CeO2 phase follows the order in these catalysts: meso‑CeCoOx-300 (6.3 nm) < meso‑CeCoOx-400 (6.8 nm) < meso‑CeCoOx-500 (7.7 nm) < meso‑CeCoOx-600 (7.8 nm). Obviously, the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst shows a relatively small crystal size. The smaller the crystal size of CeO2, the more active sites and the better the catalytic performance. To further understand the internal molecular structure of catalyst samples, raman analysis of meso‑CeCoOx catalysts was performed, as shown in Fig. 4c. The peak at 460 cm−1 corresponds to the F2g mode of the fluorite-type structure of cerium oxide, and the band around 600 cm−1 is attributed to the inherent oxygen vacancies of Ce3+ in CeO2 [31,32]. Interestingly, the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst showed a relatively obvious weak peak at 600 cm−1, while the other three samples did not show a weak peak. The results showed that there were more Ce3+ species in the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst, which resulted in the highest amount of oxygen defects in the meso‑CeCoOx-300 sample. Compared with other three samples, the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst showed better activity, indicating that higher Ce3+ species would lead to more oxygen defects in the catalyst, thereby accelerating the catalytic oxidation of toluene. In addition, the peak at 689 cm−1 is attributed to the A1g symmetric pattern of Co3O4 0 [31]. 3.3.4 FTIR spectra analysis The possible functional groups and chemical bonds in meso‑ZIF-67@CeO2 and meso‑CeCoOx-300 samples were illustrated by FTIR, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . For the meso‑ZIF-67@CeO2 sample, the peaks at 3173.9 cm−1 and 2922.7 cm−1 correspond to the tensile vibrations of -OH and -CH, respectively. The peaks at 1301.6 and 1422.9 cm−1 correspond to the tensile vibration of the imidazole ring, and the bands at 676.6 and 746.2 cm−1 correspond to the out-of-plane vibration of the imidazole ring. The peak centered at 995.0 cm−1 is related to the structure of CeO2, and the band at 428 cm−1 belongs to Co-N tensile vibration. In addition, carbon tensile vibration was observed at 1568.6 cm−1 [33–35]. For the meso‑CeCoOx-300 sample, the peaks at 3173.9 and 1627.8 cm−1 correspond to the tensile vibrations of -OH and adsorbed water molecules. The peak at 1384.1 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of -COO-, the peak centered at 1016.1 cm−1 was related to the structure of CeO2, and the peak at 667.4 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of the Co-O bond [30]. The precursor meso‑ZIF-67@CeO2 and the catalyst meso‑CeCoOx-300 have no vibration peaks belonging to SBA-15, indicating that the mesoporous silica template has been completely removed. In addition, no vibration peak of ZIF-67 was observed for meso‑CeCoOx-300, indicating that meso‑ZIF-67@CeO2 after calcination at 300 °C was successfully converted into meso‑CeCoOx-300. 3.4 Chemical properties of catalyst surface The relative atomic content (Fig. S3 and Table S1) and chemical state of the catalyst surface were detected by XPS, as shown in Fig. 6 . The XPS spectra of Ce 3d for the four meso‑CeCoOx catalysts are shown in Fig. 6a. They were used to determine the oxidation states of cerium ions, and the labeled U and V peaks were assigned as 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spin-orbit double peaks, with Ce 3d3/2 having a peak of V0-V3 and Ce 3d5/2 having a peak of U0-U3 [36]. The peaks labeled U1 (884.6–885.8 eV) and V1 (903.0–904.4 eV) represent Ce3+, and the peaks labeled U0 (882.8–883.5 eV), U2 (888.3–889.5 eV), U3 (898.9–899.5 eV), V0 (901.4–901.9 eV), V2 (907.9–908.4 eV), V3 (917.2–917.9 eV) peaks are expressed as Ce4+ [37,38]. Based on previous reports [39,40], and Raman analysis, it was confirmed that the oxygen vacancy was crucial for the adsorption of toluene. Generally, Ce3+ species will cause the generation of oxygen vacancies, so a higher concentration of Ce3+ species means a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies at the surface. Therefore, the content of Ce3+ species in the meso‑CeCoOx catalyst can be used to quantitatively evaluate the content of oxygen vacancy. Table 4 calculates the contents of Ce3+ and Ce4+, and the ratios of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) and Ce4+/(Ce3++Ce4+) were calculated by the corresponding peak area. From Table 4, the content of Ce3+ species on the catalyst surface is as follows: meso‑CeCoOx-300 (16.6%) > meso‑CeCoOx-400 (16.2%) > meso‑CeCoOx-500 (15.3%) > meso‑CeCoOx-600 (15.2%). These results indicate that the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst exhibits more Ce3+ species and oxygen vacancies. The Co 2p XPS of the four catalysts is shown in Fig. 6b. Co 2p shows two peaks, namely Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2. The Co 2p3/2 spectrum shows that the peaks at binding energies of about 780.6–780.8 eV and 782.5–782.89 eV belong to Co3+ and Co2+, respectively. The Co 2p1/2 spectrum shows that the binding energy is about 795.8–796.4 eV and the peaks at 797.5–798.1 eV belong to Co3+ and Co2+, respectively [41,42]. The peak at 786.5–787.1 eV belongs to the satellite peak. These results indicate that the Co species of the meso‑CeCoOx catalyst is involved in the formation of the Co3O4 crystal phase, which is consistent with the conclusion of XRD. In general, the Co3+ species are crucial to determine the catalytic performance of Co-based catalysts in the toluene oxidation reaction. Therefore, the percentage of Co3+ species (Co3+/(Co2++Co3++Sat.)) was calculated and shown in Table 4. From Table 4, the content of Co3+ on the catalyst surface is as follows: meso‑CeCoOx-300 (53.54%) > meso‑CeCoOx-400 (44.22%) > meso‑CeCoOx-500 (43.69%) > meso‑CeCoOx-600 (43.13%). The meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst has a higher content of Co3+ species, which indicates that a higher content of Co3+ is a favorable factor for promoting the catalytic oxidation of toluene. The O species also play a key role in improving the catalytic performance of catalysts. Therefore, the O 1 s XPS analysis was performed on the four catalysts in Fig. 6c. The peaks at 530.0–530.5 eV, 531.1–531.6 eV, and 533.0–533.1 eV are attributed to the contributions of lattice oxygen (Olatt), surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads), and surface adsorbed water (Owat), respectively [43,44]. The percentage of Olatt (Olatt/(Olatt+Oads+Owat)) and Oads (Oads/(Olatt+Oads+Owat)) are summarized in Table 4. The surface percentage of the lattice oxygen species (Olatt) is observed as follows: meso‑CeCoOx-300 (43.97%) > meso‑CeCoOx-400 (38.95%) > meso‑CeCoOx-500 (33.79%) > meso‑CeCoOx-600 (35.68%). The results showed that meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst has more Olatt species, and higher lattice oxygen species produce oxygen vacancies. Thus, it is confirmed that the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst has more oxygen vacancies, and the result is consistent with Ce 3d XPS. Combined with the activity data, it is shown that more lattice oxygen species will generate more oxygen vacancies, thereby promoting the catalytic oxidation of toluene. In addition, we also use O2-TPD to verify the type of oxygen in the catalyst. 3.5 Redox behavior of catalyst To investigate the reduction performance of the sample, the meso‑CeO2 and meso‑CeCoOx catalysts were analyzed by H2-TPR, as shown in Fig. 7 . According to previously reported results, it is known that CeO2 usually consists of two significant peaks: a low-temperature peak at about 500 °C (weak) and a high-temperature peak at 800 °C (strong). These two peaks correspond to the reduction of surface oxygen and bulk oxygen of CeO2, respectively. In addition, according to literature reports [31,32,45], Co3O4 has two reduction peaks, which are related to the gradual reduction of Co3O4 to cobalt oxide and the reduction of cobalt oxide to metallic Co. As shown in the figure, the main signals of the four catalysts were significantly transferred to a lower temperature compared with the H2-TPR of pure CeO2 and pure Co3O4. For the four samples, the characteristic peak in the temperature range of 180–350 °C, the low temperature peak is due to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, while the high temperature peak is due to the reduction of CoO to metal Co [46]. The reduction peaks at 398 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-300), 402 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-400), 433 °C(meso‑CeCoOx-500) and 450 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-600) are attributed to the surface oxygen reduction of CeO2. The reduction peaks at 619 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-300), 621 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-400), 652 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-500) and 691 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-600) correspond to the bulk oxygen reduction of CeO2. It is speculated that the insertion of cobalt into the cerium lattice may significantly reduce the reduction temperature of surface and lattice oxygen due to the strong redox reaction between Co species and Ce species. This finding indicates that there are many synergistic interactions between Co3O4 and CeO2 in the four catalysts. In addition, comparing meso‑CeCoOx catalysts with different calcination temperatures, the reduction peak of meso‑CeCoOx-300 appears at a lower temperature, which indicates that the reducibility of meso‑CeCoOx-300 is higher than that of other samples, which may be due to the different interaction between cobalt and cerium and the different valence of metal particles due to calcination temperature. For another, the reduction peak moving to low temperature to low temperature may be related to the size of the Co nanoparticles, and the small particle size is favorable for preferential reduction [47]. 3.6 O2-TPD and NH3-TPD To study the oxygen mobility on the catalyst, O2-TPD measurement was carried out, as shown in Fig. 8 . All the catalysts have no obvious peak at 100–700 °C, indicating that there is almost no desorption peak of chemisorbed oxygen on all the samples. The peak at 790 °C is related to the desorption of lattice oxygen [48]. In the process of catalytic combustion of toluene, the surface acidity is very important to determine the adsorption of the reactants. Therefore, the NH3-TPD test was performed on the four catalysts, as shown in Fig. 9 . The NH3 desorption curve in Fig. 9 can be fitted into two peaks in the range of 100–600 °C. According to the literature [49,50], the temperature range of ammonia can be determined according to the strength of the acid center of the catalyst. Peaks below 200 °C are weakly acidic sites, and peaks from 200 °C to 400 °C are moderately acidic sites. The peaks at 165.5 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-300), 167.5 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-400), 167.9 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-500) and 165.1 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-600) correspond to weak acid sites. The peaks at 266.3 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-300), 270.0 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-400), 280.9 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-500) and 250.3 °C (meso‑CeCoOx-600) were moderately strong acid sites. Table 5 summarizes the percentage of weak acid sites. The results showed that the content of weak acid sites on the surface of these samples was in the order of meso‑CeCoOx-300 (68.6%) > meso‑CeCoOx-400 (67.3%) > meso‑CeCoOx-500 (53.3%) > meso‑CeCoOx-600 (49.6%). Based on previous research [51,52], the weak acid sites are propitious to the adsorption of toluene molecules, and especially the contribution of Lewis acid sites and lattice oxygen can weaken and break greatly the C–H bands derived from methyl (–CH3) of toluene. In addition, comparing the activity data, the results verify that the weak acid sites on the surface are more conducive to the catalytic oxidation of toluene. 3.7 Proposed reaction mechanism The XPS of the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst before and after the toluene combustion reaction is used to evaluate the possible reaction mechanism of the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 10 and Table 4. By XPS analysis of the surface composition and valence states of the pre-reaction (meso‑CeCoOx-300) and post-reaction (meso‑CeCoOx-300-used), there was almost no difference in the peak position before and after the reaction. From Table 4, it is discovered that the surface Ce3+ content of the meso‑CeCoOx-300-used catalyst dropped to 15.40% after reaction. This indicates that the catalytic oxidation reaction of toluene will promote the conversion of Ce3+→Ce4+, thereby consuming the part of Ce3+ species. The surface Co3+ content dropped from 53.54% to 46.92% after the reaction, indicating that Co3+ species converted to Co2+ in the catalytic reaction of toluene combustion. Meanwhile, the surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) content decreased from 43.97% to 35.68%. This further shows that lattice oxygen plays a key role in the catalytic reaction of toluene combustion. Therefore, the reaction mechanism over the CeCoOx catalyst surface may be based on our research results and literature [48]. According to previous studies [53,54], the catalytic oxidation of toluene is carried out through a redox cycle on the catalyst. The reaction mechanism of toluene catalytic oxidation was summarized and described in Scheme 2. According to the conclusions of O 1 s XPS and O2-TPD, it is clear that the lattice oxygen (Olatt) species promotes the development of the reaction and the formation of oxygen vacancies, and plays a key role in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. Therefore, the Mars van Krevelen mechanism is more consistent with the oxidation mechanism of the catalyst surface. During the entire oxidation cycle, when toluene is introduced into the catalyst system, it is adsorbed and activated on the surface-active center of the catalyst. Ce3+ and Co3+ become the active substances for the catalytic oxidation of toluene, and Ce3+ and Co3+ produce a synergistic catalytic effect. The adsorbed toluene molecules react with the adjacent lattice oxygen species to generate some intermediate substances, such as benzene (C6H5 CH2), benzene alcohol (C6H5 CH2O-), benzoate (C6H5COO), phenol (C6H5OH), anhydrides, short-chain carbonates [30,39], etc. Finally, the adsorbed intermediates were completely oxidized to CO2 and H2O on the surface catalyst. In the oxidation process, the consumption of lattice oxygen will lead to oxygen vacancies, and then the gaseous oxygen molecules of the reaction gas will be adsorbed and refilled to the adjacent oxygen vacancies to form new lattice oxygen. Until now, a catalytic oxidation cycle has been completed. Furthermore, the ordered mesoporous channels provide sufficient limited space for the good dispersion of Ce and Co nanoparticles. In the meantime, the mesoporous structure also limits the aggregation of metal oxides and keeps the metal particles smaller in nanometer size. Thus, a large number of more effective active centers can be exposed to accelerate the catalytic oxidation of toluene. 3.8 Stability and water resistance of meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst Finally, the thermal stability of the catalyst plays an important role in the industrial application of the catalyst, so we conducted a stability test on meso‑CeCoOx-300 (Fig. 11 a). We have studied the thermal stability of meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst under different toluene conversion conditions during toluene oxidation. In the beginning, when the reaction temperature is 200 °C, the conversion rate of toluene is maintained at about 30%. After the reaction time reaches 1800 min, the conversion rate of toluene can still be maintained at about 30%. When the reaction temperature is 220 °C, the conversion rate of toluene remains at about 95% after the reaction time has passed 1800 min. This indicates that the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst has good long-term thermal stability. As we know, in addition to the thermal stability of catalysts, the toxicity resistance of catalysts is of great significance for their practical application in large-scale production. Thus, 10% water was introduced into the toluene oxidation reactor to study the effect of water vapor on the activity of the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst (Fig. 11b). Relatively high toluene conversion was selected to detect the deactivation of the catalyst during the reaction. Therefore, the oxidation reaction temperature of toluene was controlled to 220 °C, the toluene conversion rate was 95%, and the results of water resistance were shown in Fig. 11b. It was observed that when 10% volume water vapor entered the reactor, the toluene conversion rate dropped from 95% to 78% and remained stable for 20 h. However, toluene conversion gradually resumes when the steam shuts off after about 20 h. This phenomenon suggests that the inactivation of Co-based catalysts in the presence of water vapor may be attributed to the competitive adsorption of water molecules and toluene [55], which slightly inhibits the catalytic activity of the catalyst. At the same time, we explored the cycle stability of the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 11c. Fig. 11c shows the conversion of toluene when the meso‑CeCoOx-300 is used for three consecutive runs. It can be seen from Fig. 11c that there is almost no difference between the three curves, indicating that meso‑CeCoOx-300 exhibits similar catalytic activity to toluene combustion in three consecutive operations and the curve of toluene conversion and temperature has good repeatability. Therefore, it is shown that meso‑CeCoOx-300 has good cyclic stability. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, two-dimensional ordered mesoporous CeO2 metal oxide was prepared by "nano-casting technique" using two-dimensional ordered mesoporous silicon oxide (SBA-15) as a hard template. On this basis, a new vacuum in-situ confinement encapsulation strategy was proposed, in which Co-MOFs were embedded and anchored into ordered mesoporous CeO2 structure to prepare a precursor of Co-MOFs@CeO2 composites with ordered mesoporous channel structure. Finally, the Co-MOFs@CeO2 precursor was transformed into CeCoOx bimetallic oxide by precisely controlling the calcination temperature without destroying the ordered mesoporous structure. We found that the meso‑CeCoOx-300 catalyst owns excellent catalytic activity (T90=220 °C) and good stability for toluene catalytic oxidation. Through a series of chemical characterizations, it is confirmed that the presence of more Ce3+ and Co3+ species, more lattice oxygen species, smaller Co nanoparticles, and weak acid sites are some key factors to improve the activity and stability of the meso‑CeCoOx catalyst. The reaction mechanism may be related to the presence of Ce3+ and Co3+ species. Generally, Ce3+ species will cause the generation of oxygen vacancies, so a higher concentration of Ce3+ species means a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies on the surface. More importantly, we discovered that the active Co species would migrate and aggregate with the increase of calcination temperature, and affected greatly the interaction between Ce and Co. In addition, the increase of calcination temperature also resulted in an obvious decrease of the specific surface area and Co3+ species (TOFs) of the catalysts, which affected the catalytic oxidation activity of toluene. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, a novel vacuum in-situ confined encapsulation strategy was proposed, in which Co-MOFs were embedded and anchored into ordered mesoporous CeO2 structure to obtain a precursor of Co-MOF@CeO2 composites. Accordingly, the Co-MOF@CeO2 precursor was transformed into ordered mesoporous CeCoOx oxides for catalytic combustion of toluene by precisely controlling their calcination temperature without destroying the ordered mesoporous structure. It is confirmed that order meso‑CeCoOx-300 calcined at 300 °C had superior activity and good thermal stability for toluene catalytic oxidation, which were chiefly due to the content of Co3+, the effective anchoring of Co-MOFs in ordered mesoporous CeO2, more lattice oxygen, and weak acid sites. More importantly, we discovered that the active Co species would migrate and aggregate with the increase of calcination temperature, and affected greatly the interaction between Ce and Co. Besides, the increase of calcination temperature also resulted in an obvious decrease of the specific surface area and Co3+ species (TOFs) of the catalysts, which affected the catalytic combustion activity of toluene.
coredata.dc:title: Engineering order mesoporous CeCoOx catalyst via in-situ confined encapsulation strategy for VOCs catalytic combustion
